author: @ryanthompson591
text: I found when getting the army to attack I got much better performance with the default attack.  For example if you specify an enemy to attack it won't necessarily attack the closest one and might walk through a bunch of attacking fire.  If you do a location attack then it will attack what's closest.  Here's the code I used.  await self.do(unit.attack(random.choice(self.known_enemy_units).position))  This could go wrong if the enemy unit is far and moves away from the attack position, but I did give me better performance.

author: @ninjalacoon
text: One other suggestion I can make to further improve the power of the sentebot ai, especially where protoss units are considered, is the idea of recycling your units during a fight. You would need to add some logic to micromanage your combat units so that during an engagement weakened units move to the back of your army and recharge their shields while still shooting and allow for your other full health/shield units to take some of the heat. You can probably imagine that this allows you to give your fighting force a lot more longevity and eek out even more value from them without spending more resources or waiting for more units to be mustered.

author: @ninjalacoon
text: The pylons being placed in the path of the workers collecting resources is an area where things might be further optimized, but I guess before even considering that you probably want to spend all those excess resources as you mentioned. Worker efficiency though is pretty important in sc2. Fun tut.

text: I ended up losing when I tried the Medium AI, although it took a really long time because my drones sort of played hide and seek with Nexuses and kept building new ones in other locations while the old ones were being destroyed. I think I went through 8 or 9 of them before they finally destroyed the last one.  Something goes really weird with Nexus placement when at least one has been destroyed. Drones start building them in odd locations that are equidistant from multiple mineral sites but not really close to any of them.

author: @azthecx
text: In StarCraft macro is ridiculously overpowered, that's why you're having such an easy time vs AI because your macro can easily keep your resources very low. Even with your current logic if you just kept adding Gateways and massing stalkers you would likely have won versus hard.  Macro is macro-management, how well you spend your money, upgrade your units, build more buildings.  Also since you seem to have infinite APM (Actions per Minute) you likely can get the Blink upgrade for the stalkers and just faceroll most AI's by blinking your weak Stalkers to the back. This would be micro.

author: @TheMcal9909
text: Limiting the population of workers by using the ideal amount of harvesters for each of your harvesting buildings. Assimilators is 3 and Nexus is 16(when surrounded by minerals). You can get this using the API.  .ideal_harvesters can be used on each Nexus and Assimilator and just set your worker limit to the sum of this.  I have used .ideal_harvesters to stop building Assimilators near a Nexus that doesnt have its ideal amount harvesting minerals.. I found i had to much gas later game and compared to minerals. Speeds up the early game a little aswell.

author: @husky090689
text: I may be mistaken but you may want to look into "await self.do(unit.attack(self.known_enemy_units.prefer_close_to(unit.position)[0].position))"  As far as I know, 'prefer_close_to' sorts known enemy units by distance to you unit and by choosing the first one [0] you attack the closest one.  Also (and here I'm not certain) I think that by passing '.position' to the attack method you are ordering an "attack move" of the location instead of direct attack of specific unit - so your unit will attack anything it encounters on the way instead of chasing that one specific unit. (that's what I've noticed from experimenting)
